conclusion: Analyze the acceleration-time graph to determine velocity at t=60s.
Graph shows acceleration a(t) as a function of time t.
Acceleration is positive when speeding up, negative when slowing down.
Area under acceleration-time graph gives change in velocity.
Calculate velocity for interval 0 to 1 second: Area = 1 m/s, v(1) = 1 m/s.
Calculate velocity for interval 1 to 4 seconds: Area = 6 m/s, v(4) = 7 m/s.
Calculate velocity for interval 4 to 5 seconds: Area = 1 m/s, v(5) = 8 m/s.
Calculate velocity for interval 5 to 55 seconds: Velocity remains constant, v(55) = 8 m/s.
Calculate velocity for interval 55 to 56 seconds: Area = -1 m/s, v(56) = 7 m/s.
Calculate velocity for interval 56 to 59 seconds: Area = -6 m/s, v(59) = 1 m/s.
Calculate velocity for interval 59 to 60 seconds: Area = -1 m/s, v(60) = 0 m/s.
Final answer: Speed of the elevator at t=60s is 0 m/s.
